journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part N: Journal of Nanoengineering and Nanosystems

title-group.article-title: Electrohydrodynamic impulse printing PANI sensor for NH3 gas

contrib-group.aff: School of Physics and Mechanical and Electrical Engineering, Xiamen University, People’s Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: Dezhi Wu, School of Physics and Mechanical and Electrical Engineering, Xiamen University, Xiamen 361005, People’s Republic of China. Email: wdz@xmu.edu.cn

abstract.p: Electrohydrodynamic impulse printing is utilized to fabricate polyaniline droplets from protonic acid doped polyaniline, which can be composed to form lines as micro NH3 sensing elements. The effect of applied voltage, voltage frequency and voltage duty ratio on pattern size is investigated. The results show the size decreases with the frequency and voltage, but increases with the duty ratio. A minimum width line of 92 µm is obtained when applied voltage, voltage frequency, duty ratio, nozzle tip to substrate distance and flow rate are set to be 2450 V, 40%, 70 Hz, 1 mm and 100 µl/h, respectively. When exposed to NH3 gas, electrohydrodynamic printed polyaniline lines have a rapid response time to NH3. A minimum concentration of about 300 ppm of NH3 can be detected.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Protonic acid doped polyaniline (PANI) is a conductive polymer, which is characterized by simple and reversible doping/dedoping chemistry, stable electrical conduction mechanism, and high environmental stability; it has been used as a sensing material for varieties of toxic gases such as CO, NO2, and NH3.1,2 Because of the influence of the removal of a proton, the conductivity of PANI with p-type semiconductor characteristics will decrease when exposed to such gases.3,4

As a result of its high surface to volume ratio, electrospun PANI nanofiber is highly sensitive to chemical gas.5 But owing to the chaotic behavior and low viscosity of PANI solution, it is difficult to deposit the as-spun nanofiber precisely onto the substrate, which hinders the application of PANI in micro sensors.6 Electrohydrodynamic (EHD) impulse printing is introduced to fabricate discrete droplets under the impulse high voltage and this process can avoid the problems encountered in electrospinning.7,8 At present, EHD impulse printing has exhibited great application potential in the fabrication of flexible electronics and micro/nano systems. In the process, solution is supplied to the capillary nozzle at a low flow rate. Applying a high impulse voltage to the solution, a strong electrostatic force can be generated to deform the liquid meniscus into a sharp cone called a Taylor cone. When the electrostatic force is large enough to overcome its surface tension, the charged jet can be ejected discontinuously from the tip of the cone. With solvent evaporation, micro drops deposit on the substrate.9 Consequently, EHD printing is an excellent materials patterning technology and different patterns can be obtained by adjusting the motion track and velocity of the collector.

sec.title: Experiment
sec.p: As shown in Figure 1(a), the set-up consists of a syringe pump (Harvard 11 PLUS, USA), a capillary nozzle (inner diameter d0 is 0.2 mm), a high-voltage impulse power supply (HVP-402 NP1, Tianjin), an X−Y stage and a motor controller. The collector is composed of two parallel electrodes with an insulated gap of 1 mm. In the experiment, 0.10 g polyaniline emeraldine base (Sigma Aldrich, Mw = 100,000) and 0.129 g 10-camphorsulfonic acid (Sigma Aldrich, Mw=232.3 g/mol) is dissolved in 10 ml chloroform (Guangdong Xilong Chemical Co., Ltd) to obtain a mixed solution with a concentration of 1.5 wt%. Then the solution is stirred at room temperature overnight. Subsequently, the dark green solution is filtered with a 0.45 µm/25 mm syringe filter to remove the relatively larger particulate substances. Finally, polyethylene oxide (PEO, Dadi Fine Chemical Co., Ltd, Mw=5000,000) is added to change the viscosity of the solution. The morphologies of printing structures are characterized by optical microscope.

caption.p: (a) EHD printing set-up; (b) NH3 gas test system.

sec.p: A test system is built up to measure the response of the PANI line to NH3 and the sensing signal can be recorded in a real-time manner. A schematic diagram of the sensing system is shown in Figure 1(b). When NH3 is added into a container, the PANI line which is deposited to bridge those two electrodes will be oxidized by the volatilized NH3. Applying a direct current (DC) power potential to the electrodes, the corresponding current through the line is amplified by I–V amplifier (OPA129) and the signal is recorded at the rate of two data per second by an Agilent 34410A multi-meter.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: The experiment shows that the solution mixed with 0.2 wt% PEO can only be spun rather than printed. If the concentration is lower than 0.1 wt%, the printing process can be activated owing to the solution’s proper viscoelasticity, as shown in Figure 2. The main disadvantage of electrospinning is the chaotic nature of the nanofiber on the collector. However, the same speed of the X−Y stage is used to collect the droplets of the EHD printing and the desired patterns can be achieved. Therefore, the solution with 0.1 wt% PEO is utilized in the following experiments.

caption.p: Two-dimensional pattern: (a) EHD printing (0.1% PEO); (b) electrospinning (0.2% PEO)

sec.p: In order to obtain small-scale patterns, two evaluation parameters are taken into consideration: one is the diameter of the droplets, which affects the pattern size directly; the other is ejection frequency (the reciprocal of time interval between deposition points), which affects the width of printing lines and determines the speed of the stage to avoid accumulation of the adjacent droplet. In this paper, the effects of the key parameters of EHD impulse printing, such as applied voltage V, voltage frequency fvol and duty ratio δ on pattern size are studied.

sec.title: Applied voltage
sec.p: As shown in Figure 3(a) to (e), droplets are achieved when the applied voltage ranges from 2200 V to 2500 V (approaching the breakdown voltage) on the reference condition of a 1.5 mm nozzle tip to substrate distance (d), 100 µl/h flow rate (Q) and 50 Hz voltage frequency. As applied voltage increases, correspondingly the average diameter of droplets decreases from 426 µm to 220 µm, but the ejection frequency (fliq) varies from 10.58 Hz to 32 Hz. The relationship between diameter of printing droplets and ejection frequency plotted against applied voltage is displayed in Figure 3(f).

caption.p: (a), (b), (c), (d), (e) Printing droplets under different applied voltage; (f) the relationship between diameter of printing droplets and ejection frequency plotted against applied voltage. Reference condition: d = 1.5 mm, δ = 70%, Q = 100 µl/h, fvol = 50 Hz

sec.p: Xu et al.10 have discussed the diameter of droplets decreasing with the increase of applied voltage, which results from greater stretching on the fluid cone. On the other hand, because the diameter of the droplets (ddrop) is proportional to (Q/fliq)1/3, the fliq value increases when Q is constant.

Adjusting the moving stage, the continuous lines are printed under corresponding conditions, as shown in Figure 4(a) to (d). Trend of the width variation is the same as for the droplets; width of the lines also decreases according to increasing voltage. However, compared to the diameter of the droplets, the printing line is slightly thicker and non-uniform in some parts. The differences between the droplets and lines confirm the previous forecast that thicker patterns result from an accumulation of adjacent droplets.

caption.p: (a), (b), (c), (d) PANI printing lines under different applied voltage. Reference condition: d = 1.5 mm, δ = 70%, Q = 100 µl/h, fvol = 50 Hz.

sec.title: Voltage frequency
sec.p: The printing droplets under different voltage frequencies (5–60 Hz) are plotted in Figure 5(a) to (d). The diameter changes from 725 µm (fvol = 5 Hz) to 68 µm (fvol = 60 Hz). A dramatic decrease in size suggests a significant role of the fvol. As shown in Figure 5(e), fliq tends to be 1/N of the fvol, which is consistent with the results discussed by Xu et al.10

caption.p: (a), (b), (c), (d) PANI printing droplets under different voltage frequencies; (e) the relationship between 5 Hz and 60 Hz. Reference condition: d = 1 mm, δ = 70%, Q = 100 µl/h, V = 2400 V.

sec.p: Moreover, according to the mass conservation equation, the flow rate of the solution is equal to fliq multiplied by the volume of droplets. In the EHD printing process flow rate is constant, and fliq tends to match up with the variation of fvol. As a consequence of increasing fvol, smaller droplets are achieved.

sec.title: Voltage duty ratio
sec.p: Voltage duty ratio is another factor that affects the printing process. Figure 6(a) to (f) shows the printing droplets under different voltage duty ratio δ when nozzle tip to substrate distance, applied voltage and flow rate are 2400 V, 1.5 mm and 100 µl/h, respectively. The diameter of the droplets increases from 220 µm to 450 µm when voltage duty ratio increases from 10% to 90%. It is believed that the increasing of duty ratio extends the time that the electrostatic force is applied on the droplets. Therefore, higher kinetic energy results in larger diameter, when droplets impact on the substrate.11

caption.p: (a), (b), (c), (d), (e), (f) PANI droplets under different voltage duty ratio; (g) the relationship between diameter of droplets and ejection frequency plotted against voltage duty ratio; voltage duty ratio ranges from 10% to 90%. Reference condition: d = 1.5 mm, Q = 100 µl/h, fvol = 50 Hz, V = 2400 V.

sec.title: Gas sensing
sec.p: Based on the above EHD printing results, the optimal line can be printed with relatively high voltage (2400–2450 V), high voltage frequency (>50 Hz) and low duty ratio (10–50%). The width of the line will diminish to 9 2µm when applied voltage, voltage frequency, duty ratio, nozzle tip to substrate distance and flow rate are set to be 2450 V, 40%, 70 Hz, 1 mm and 100 µl/h.

As a sensing element, the sensor performance is included in the investigation. Three sensing elements, with line widths of 100 µm, 180 µm and 200 µm, were investigated when NH3 concentration was 560 ppm. The response property of the sensor is shown in Figure 7(a). With the width decreasing, the response time reduces from 100 s to 13 s, the line for 100 µm has the most rapid response owing to the increase in surface to volume ratio. In addition, the sensing line with 100 µm width was placed in different NH3 concentrations; the response curves are shown in Figure 7(b). It can be concluded that the response time deceases with NH3 concentration; also, it is found that a minimum concentration of about 300 ppm of NH3 can be detected.

caption.p: (a) The response time of NH3 with line widths 100 µm, 180 µm and 200 µm. (b) The response time of NH3 with NH3 concentrations 200 ppm, 300 ppm and 560 ppm.

sec.title: Summary
sec.p: PANI droplets are fabricated via EHD printing to compose lines as NH3 sensing elements. In order to obtain a better printing result, the parameters influencing droplet diameter and ejection frequency are discussed. According to the effect of the parameters, an average line width of 92 µm is obtained when applied voltage, voltage frequency, nozzle tip to substrate distance and flow rate are set to be 2450 V, 40 Hz, 1 mm and 100 µl/h. The test results show that the PANI line has a rapid response time for NH3 and the minimum concentration that can be detected is about 300 ppm. It is believed that EHD printing provides an excellent method of micro fabrication.

fn.p: The research was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (grant number 51035002, 50875222) and the Natural Science Foundation of Fujian Province of China (grant number 2011J05139).
